text: Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: How soon would I feel any? Doctor: Probably about three weeks. Patient: About three weeks? Doctor: Um hum. Yeah. Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway?

text: Patient: It passes freely. (Pause) Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I think I do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I did take iron. text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.

text: Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause)

text: Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You have Provenge. Um, so um, the one standard thing that’s left is a radiation-based thing but that’s really only for disease of the bone. You have lymph node as well. So I would sort of not use that. The other thing that’s left is chemotherapy, flavors, uh so that’s something we could always go to. The other sort of unfortunately gray zone (beeping) Patient: Sure. Doctor: Uh and some of that’s clinical trial. A lot of the clinical trials we have right now are hormonal based. So it’s Zytiga plus something, Xtandi plus something. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Versus something. So unfortunately uh you wouldn’t fit all those trials because of the prior treatments we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
